Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Integrative species delimitation, cryptic coloration, and climatic niche breadth in songbirds
Award.AbstractNarration:
All species exhibit some level of phenotypic variation, such that individuals and populations differ in their appearance. The amount of phenotypic diversity and the number of species, however, vary dramatically among different types of organisms and regions of the world. Understanding the evolutionary and ecological processes that cause differences in the number of species among different groups of organisms and geographic regions is a longstanding goal in evolutionary biology. This research first seeks to improve our estimation of the number of species of horned locks, which would help in better understanding how biodiversity evolves and is maintained. This project will then measure geographic variation in camouflage by quantifying how feather coloration on the backs of larks matches the color and composition of the ground among different populations. Species that possess distinct forms of camouflage, or background matching, have provided some of society's most celebrated examples of natural selection; yet we lack an understanding of the evolutionary and ecological dynamics behind such complex, subtle, and continuous patterns of color variation related to camouflage. This research will advance our understanding of how animals adapt to environmental conditions that vary over space and time. The researchers will actively recruit and train undergraduate research assistants from underrepresented demographic groups in science to complete this work. This project will also generate online educational resources and popular science articles to educate the public about natural selection and camouflage in nature.

This research proposes an integrative study of phenotypic and genetic differentiation within a recent, widespread, and highly polytypic lineage of larks in the bird genus Eremophila. The project will leverage traditionally data sources, including multiple forms of remote sensing data, digital photography, and ancient DNA from museum toepads via Sequence Capture using PCR-generated Probes (SCPP), to delimit species and undertake comparative analyses of cryptic coloration. Using SCPP, the researchers will generate a panel of 60 loci, including the mitochondrial genome, sex-linked markers, and autosomal introns and exons, for phylogeographic analyses and integrative species delimitation alongside phenotypic variation in song, plumage, and morphology. Upon delimiting species and resolving relationships within the genus, the project will use the revised taxonomy and corresponding species tree to quantify the prevalence of geographic variation in cryptic coloration--or the degree of background matching between dorsal plumage and corresponding substrates--among populations and species. Finally, the project will test whether the amount of variation in cryptic coloration is correlated with abiotic niche breadth among species in Eremophila, which would suggest that evolvability of cryptic coloration plays an important role facilitating range expansions into different habitats.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Co-PI Mason and Co-PI Lovette studied variation in DNA, plumage, and habitat characteristics among populations in a widespread species of bird, the Horned Lark (Eremophila alpestris). The PIs developed a lab workflow to extract genomic regions of DNA from toepads and feathers. This genetic information was then used to reconstruct historical relationships among lark populations from five different continents.

As part of this pipeline, the PIs generated the first full reference genome from any lark species. They used this genome to test for gene regions involved in adaptation among different populations of horned lark. The PIs incorporated these new data into a study that revises the taxonomy of this group, such that we have a better understanding of how many lark species exist within the group, where they are located, and what they look like. This information improves our understanding of biodiversity of an understudied group of birds and it provides important information to aid conservation efforts of threatened populations of Horned Lark in the western USA.

To explore how different lark populations are matched to their environments, the investigators also measured the coloration of the backs of lark specimens in museums to study how lark populations vary in camouflage. Horned larks live in open areas and rely on a close match between the color of their back and the soil to avoid being eaten by raptors. Co-PI Mason carefully measured hundreds of specimens and quantified the color and patterning on the back of each lark. This study revealed a close association between the amount of patterning on the back and the composition of the soil at the site where the lark lived, such that more heavily streaked individuals occurred in soil with more pebbles and stones, while less streaked individuals occupied more clay-rich soil that is composed of finer-grain material. These findings highlight the power of natural history collections to reveal local adaptations, or instances where the environmental variation shapes the physical appearance of different populations within a species.

Using a similar approach to document variation in lark coloration, the PIs documented an instance of rapid change in lark coloration following changes in land use. In the Imperial Valley of California, the light natural desert soil is much differerent in color than are the darker soils that have been irrigated and tilled for crop production. These two soil colors exist side-by-side, and larks occur in each. Prior to extensive irrigation in this region, all local larks had light-colored feathers. Now, after nearly a century of agricultural modification of this valley, the larks living on tilled soils have notably darker feather coloration. These findings about how Imperial Valley larks have evolved to remain camouflaged as their habitat has changed illustrate one of the many ways that species and populations respond to human activity.

Finally, this project also facilitated the professional development of Co-PI Mason, who acquired through his graduate studies a wide range of laboratory and computer programming skills in order to acquire and analyze these data. The findings are now being published in scientific journals and simultaneously disseminated through oral presentations at academic conferences and seminars for public audiences.
